result.heading: T H E G R E E N M I L E

direction.raw_text: distant as a faded memory on an old Victrola: Once I built a railroad, made it run... Made it race against time...Once I built a railroad, now it's done...Brother, can you spare a dime... Opening credit sequence plays against footage of the Great Depression, images haunting and sepia-toned, defining an era. The bread lines...the soup kitchens...the dust bowl refugees heading west with their possessions on their backs and no hope in their eyes...the strutting gangster royalty flaunting their bootleg riches...an entire generation of lost youth riding the rials...the U.S. army troops raining truncheon blows on the half-starved and forgotten veterans of World War One as "Hooverville" is set afire in the very shadow of the nation's capitol... All these faces, all these lives, in a world not really so very long ago...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...where cattails sway in the sepia-toned heat. A small scrap of fabric is snagged in the nettles, fluttering languidly...

direction.raw_text: as mosquitoes swarm and dragonflies skitter, showing the fabric scrap to be pale yellow... Suddenly, a MAN WITH A SHOTGUN comes crashing through the cattails, wiping through frame and exiting... ...then ANOTHER MAN...and ANOTHER...armed with rifles, plowing through the brush, exiting frame... ...and now comes KLAUS DETTERICK, a farmer one step above shirt-tail poor, a double-barrel shotgun in the crook of his arm. He pauses, horrified, seeing the scrap of cloth. He pulls it loose, turns back, screaming something in anguish... ...and still more men come crashing into view, flooding by us with dreamlike, slow-motion grace. ONE MAN is leading a team of DOGS, trying to untangle the leads. DEPUTY ROB McGEE is shouting for everybody to stay together... ...and under it all, we hear a sibilant, frightening whisper:

He's making that inhuman howling sound, face twisted in monstrous grief, pausing occasionally to take in a great hitching breath of air. Curled in his massive arms are the naked bodies of Detterick's 9 year-old twin girls, their once-blonde hair now matted to their heads with blood. A tableau. The men staring. John Coffey howling. A train puffing smoke across the landscape. Klaus Detterick breaks the moment, lunging down the riverbank in a headlong rush. The others try to grab him, but he shrugs them off and throws himself on Coffey with a scream of inarticulate rage, kicking and punching, fists flying. Coffey barely seems to notice. The others catch up with Klaus, drag him off. He falls to his knees on the riverbank, sobbing into his hands. Howie runs to him, throws himself into his father's arm. They hug each other tightly, overwhelmed with grief. A semblance of quiet descends, except for Coffey's heartbroken wailing. A ring of rifle toting men forms around him, though he hardly seems aware of it. McGee steps forward, uncertain: McGEE Mister. Coffey goes quiet at once, eyes still streaming tears. McGEE Mister? direction.raw_text: Paul lies awake, watching Jan sleep. He looks troubled--not to mention feverish. It occurs to him how badly he has to pee. He sits up, clutching at a queasy stab of pain in his groin...

direction.raw_text: ...and he's moving even faster as he exits the kitchen, racing for the outhouse. He realizes he's not going to make it, stops to piss near the woodpile at the corner of the house... ...and as he does, he's hit with the most stunning pain of his life. He buckles to his knees--it's only his flailing hand against the woodpile that prevents him from going face- first into his own piss. He crams his other hand to his mouth in an enormous effort not to scream and wake his wife. He manages to ride it out until his bladder empties. He falls onto his side, rolls over on the grass, and stares up at the sky with both hands pressed to his groin.

direction.raw_text: --and he drops his wrist-chain down over Dean's head, jerks it tight, begins to strangle him. Dean lurches forward, Billy riding/propelling him through the door onto the Mile. Percy stands frozen in the doorway, stunned. Harry shoves him aside and jumps on Billy from behind, trying to get him off Dean. Dean is choking, turning purple. Paul rushes from the cell to join the fray. Billy whirls, delivering a stunning kick to Paul's groin. Paul's bladder pain goes nuclear--he falls back in agony, clutching himself and sucking air through his teeth, unable even to scream. dialogue.raw_text: We thought he was doped. (to Percy) Didn't we? Didn't we all of us think he was doped?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You didn't ask? I guess that's not a mistake you'll be need to make again anytime soon, is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Grab his arms! You too, Percy! (off Percy's hesitation) Percy, goddamn it, get your feet out of cement and help us out here!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Get Dean looked at right away, make sure he's all right. Percy, you go make a report to the warden for me. Start off by saying the situation is under control-- it's not a story, he won't appreciate you drawing out the suspense.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What about you? You look about ready to collapse.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've got the Mile till you all get back. Go on now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Boss? Needs ta see ya down here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is not a good time, John Coffey. Not a good time at all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) But I needs ta see ya, boss. I needs ta talk t'ya.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ...and finds Coffey waiting at his bars.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul blinks. Maybe it's the fever clouding his brain, or maybe...hell, is this what being hypnotized is like? He tries to shake the sensation off, comes a little closer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His hand shoots out, grabs Paul by the collar, jerks him close. Paul makes a panic-grab for his revolver... ...but Coffey lays his free hand atop Paul's, eases his grip from the gun--no need for that. Coffey's hand then drifts slowly down, easing to Paul's crotch...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...and something goes WHUMP through Paul's body. He arches back with his mouth agape and arms outstretched as a rush of energy seems to pass from Paul through Coffey's hand... ...and then it's over. Paul comes back to the real world, weak against the bars, realizes Del is hollering in his cell:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It dawns on him that he really is fine. Fever's gone. So is the pain in his groin. John Coffey, though, seems to be having trouble. He sits down on his bunk, bends forward, gagging like a man with a chicken bone caught in his throat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul fumbles his keys to the lock, unsure if he should open the door, watching the big man's contortions grow stronger like a cat trying to cough up a hairball... ...and then comes an unpleasant, gagging/retching sound as Coffey's lips draw back from his teeth in a kind of godawful sneer...and he exhales a cloud of what look like tiny black insects. They swirl furiously in front of his face, turn white...and disappear. Paul just stares, stunned. Softly:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Coffey shrugs--it's something that just is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He rolls onto his bunk, faces the wall. Paul just stares at him, stunned. He turns and walks up the Mile, his stiffness and pain now gone. Del watches him go by, also stunned:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul continues up the Mile...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Closer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm alone here right now, John. Figure this is close enough.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Boss, please. I got to whisper in your ear.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Boss? You know you not s'pose to do dat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mind your business, Del. What do you want, John Coffey?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just to help.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (stunned, frozen) What are you...doing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ! JOHN COFFEY'S KILLING BOSS EDGECOMB! HELP!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Del, Chrissake, settle down, I'm fine...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: John? John, what's wrong?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What did you do, big boy? What did you do to me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I helped it. Didn't I help it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, but...how?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just took it back, is all. Awful tired now, boss. Dog tired.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What dat man do to you? He throw some gris-gris on you? (off Paul's look) You look diff'int! Even walk diff'int. Like y'all better!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're imagining thing. Lie down, Del. Get you some rest.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ...and steps back into the toilet. Not trusting this situation for even a moment, Paul opens his fly, takes a deep breath to prepare himself for the pain, starts to pee... ...and we hear a healthy stream of water hitting the bowl. The look on Paul's face says it all--blessed relief.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul comes home from work, still looking numb about the whole thing. He drifts to the kitchen door. Jan's at the counter, slicing vegetables for dinner. She glances at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She turns back. Paul's eyes drift down to admire her ass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No response. He's too busy staring. She turns again--he glances hastily up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She turns back, keeps working. He crosses the room, eyeing her ass all the way...and surprised her by pressing up against her from behind, running his hands along her hips.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He starts laying kisses on the back of her neck, giving her pleasant shivers, murmuring:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's getting her breathless. She turns into his arms and they get into some passionate kissing. It's not too long before they're frantically peeling each other's clothes off...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hi, honey. How are you feeling?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Um...not too bad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What did the doctor say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, you know doctors. Gobble-de- gook mostly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Paul? What are you doing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's it feel like?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know what it feels like...it feels great...but...Paul...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ...and we find them having a wild tumble in the sheets, both moaning and groaning, sweating and panting. She pushes him flat on the bed, pauses to catch her breath...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...and they keep going, rutting like crazed weasels...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Those must've been some pills.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ...as their moans go drifting into the night...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: AS ABOVE - DAWN ...and they're still moaning up there as the sun creeps up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jan falls back, exhausted after the latest go-round. She catches her breath, looks over at Paul, and finally:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She gives him a look--oh?
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Paul? Not that I'm complaining. But we haven't gone four times in one night since we were nineteen. (off his look) You wanna tell me just what the hell's going on?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well...thing is...I never actually got to the doctor yesterday...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Paul is on the phone:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hangs up, turns to Jan.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Brutal? Listen...I'm thinking of taking the morning off sick. You cover the fort for me? (beat) That's swell. Thanks. Yeah, I'm sure I'll feel better. Okay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You sure you ought to do this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not sure what I'm sure of.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Paul's model T comes putt-putting up the road past a sign: "Trapingus County Welcomes You."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: public defender for Trapingus County, sits with a cold soda and a magazine, watching his TWO CHILDREN playing on a swing at the far end of the backyard. The screen door opens and CYNTHIA HAMMERSMITH ushers Paul out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She goes back inside. Burt rises.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Burt settles back down, motions "please sit".
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cynthia reappears, hands Paul a cold root beer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She goes back inside, but the kids aren't quite able to tear themselves away from their play.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Burt smiles, realizing:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cynthia hollers from an open window:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The kids start this way. Burt turns back to Paul.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The little boy comes to him, staring at his feet. Burt tires to raise the boy's chin. The boy resists for a moment...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...and then his face comes around. He's horribly scarred on that side, the eye missing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The boy races inside after his sister. Paul follows Burt's gaze off toward the rear of the property, where an unoccupied doghouse stands weathered and sad in the weeds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Burt acknowledges the condolence with a gracious nod.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He raises his hand, making biting motions with his fingers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul says nothing. Burt gazes out again. Softly:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I offer you a cold drink?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, ma'am, a cold drink would be fine. Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Hammersmith. Your office said I'd find you at home today. I hope I'm not troubling you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That depends, Mr.--?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Paul Edgecomb. I'm the E Block superintendant at Cold Mountain.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Green Mile. I've heard of it. Lost a few clients your way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's why I'm here. I'd like to ask you about one of them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Which client? Now you got my curiosity aroused.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: John Coffey.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah, Coffey. He causing you problems?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, can't say he is. He doesn't like the dark. He cries on occasion. Other than that...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Cries, does he? Well, he's got a lot to cry about, I'd say. You know what he did.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nods) I read the court transcripts.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you, Missus.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My pleasure. Kids! Lunch is about ready! Y'all come on up!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What exactly are you trying to find out? Satisfy my curiosity, I'll see if I can satisfy yours.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've wondered if he ever did anything like that before.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why? Has he said anything?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. But a man who does a thing like that has often developed a taste for it over time. Occurred to me it might be easy enough to follow his backtrail and find out. A man his size, and colored to boot, can't be that hard to trace.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'd think so, but you'd be wrong. Believe me, we tried. It's like he dropped out of the sky.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How do you explain that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're in a Depression. A third of the country's out of work. People are drifting by the thousands, looking for work, looking for that greener grass. Even a giant like Coffey wouldn't get noticed everywhere he goes... not until he kills a couple of little girls.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's...strange, I admit. But there doesn't seem to be any real violence in him. I know violent men, Mr. Hammersmith. I deal with 'em day in and day out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You didn't come up here to ask me whether he might have killed before. You came up here to see if I think he did it at all. That's it, isn't it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: One seldom sees a less ambiguous case. He was found with the victims in his arms. Blurted out a confession right then and there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yet you defended him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Everyone is entitled to a defense.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Kids! Lunch!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Y'all listen to your Momma, now!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tell you something. You listen close, too, because it might be something you need to know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm listening.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We had us a dog. No particular breed, but gentle. Ready to lick your hand or fetch a stick. Just a sweet mongrel, you know the kind. (Paul nods) In many way, a good mongrel dog is like you negro. You get to know it, and often you get to love it. It is of no particular use, but you keep it around because you think it loves you. If you're lucky, Mr. Edgecomb, you never have to find out any different. My wife and I were not so lucky. Caleb. Come here for a second.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please, son.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He has the one eye. I suppose he's lucky not to be blind. We get down on our knees and thank God for that much at least. Right Caleb? (the boy nods shyly) Okay, go on in now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That dog attacked my boy for no reason. Just got it into his mind one day. Same with John Coffey. He was sorry afterwards, of that I have no doubt...but those little girls stayed raped and murdered nonetheless. Maybe he's never done it before--my dog never bit before, but I didn't concern myself with that. I went out there with my rifle and grabbed his collar and blew his brains out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry for your trouble.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm as enlightened as the next man, Mr. Edgecomb. I would not bring back slavery for all the tea in China. I believe we have to be humane and generous in our efforts to solve the race problem. But we have to remember that the negro will bite if he gets the chance, just like a mongrel dog will bite if it crosses its mind to do so. (beat) Is Coffey guilty? Yes, he is. Don't you doubt it, and don't you turn your back on him. You might get away with it once or even a hundred times...but in the end...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You understand?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm gonna have to tear that old doghouse down one of these days.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Paul drives back to Cold Mountain, his heart conflicted...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...and he walks onto the Mile with a bundle wrapped in a dish towel. Brutal glances up from the desk, sniffing the air.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul continues down the Mile. Whatever he's carrying, the smell of it brings Del to his bars. Even Mr.Jingles comes skittering out of his cigar box, sniffing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul arrives at Coffey's cell. Coffey's on his bunk facing the wall. His head comes around, drawn by the aroma. He sits up, wipes the tears leaking from his eyes, looks at Paul.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul speaks softly so the others can't hear:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Coffey nods thoughtfully, absorbing this notion. Then:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul motions discreetly to his crotch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul hands him the bundle through the bars. Coffey takes it, uncovers the cornbread reverently, gazes back up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul nods. Across the way, Del is pressing his face longingly through the bars while Mr. Jingles crawls on his shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: John carefully scoops a big chunk of cornbread out with his enormous hand, holds it through the bars to Paul.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Coffey looks to Paul--do I have to?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He smiles like a big kid, digging in with his fingers. Paul crosses the Mile to Del's cell, hands him his share.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul's temper flares--he steps to Billy's cell.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Beat. Billy spits in Paul's face and follows it up with a big grin--what are you gonna do about that? Paul is seething as he wipes the spit off, but keeps his temper where it belongs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul walks away. Billy laughs, hollering after him:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: No, it's not for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh. Oh my.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm smelling me some cornbread.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's from my missus. She wanted to thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank me for what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know. For helping me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Helping you with what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ohhh. (beat) Was your missus pleased?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Several times.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This all for me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh my. John, I can smell it from here. I surely can.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looks to Paul) Can I give some to Del?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's yours, John. You do with it as you please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here's for Del and Mr. Jingles then.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey! What about me? I'm'a get some too, ain't I
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's yours, John. As you please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well. Fine. I think I'll keep the rest, then.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Courtesy of the gentleman across the way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, John. So very fine of you. So very kind. Mr. Jingles t'ank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (mouth full) ...wel'cm...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey! What about me? Don't you hold out on me, ya big dummy nigger!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'll keep a civil tongue on my block.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You get that one for free. But that's the last one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's it? Just that little bitty one? Guess I'll have to pay out for the rest, huh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Harry is walking the Mile, doing a cell check and jotting on a clipboard. He pauses, making a notation... ...and a long stream of piss hits his leg. Billy's at his bars, peeing on him. Harry jumps back, stunned. Billy howls with laughter, hosing his aim wildly from side to side.

dialogue.raw_text: Yeehaaw! Good shot, weren't it? Oh, the look on your face!

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, d'jall like that? I'm currently cooking some turds t'go with it! Nice soft ones! I'll have 'em out t'yall tomorrow!

They batter him half- senseless, then cut the water. Billy collapses in a heap. Paul and Brutal drag him semi-conscious from his cell and get the straitjacket on him. He comes around as they draw the straps tight and pull him to his feet.

direction.raw_text: Billy lets out a scream of rage and throws himself at Brutal. Brutal, bored, shoves him back toward Paul, who then propels him down the Mile toward the open restraint room door. Billy sees where they intend to put him, resorts to pleading:

dialogue.raw_text: Hey! Whassit now, movin' day? Y'all wanna come in and dust a little? Y'can shine my knob for me while yer at it!

dialogue.raw_text: You can come in here on your legs, but you'll go out on your backs, Billy the Kid guarantee ya that. (motions to Brutal) C'mon, fuckstick. No sneakin' up on me this time. We'll go man to man, see who's the better fel--

dialogue.raw_text: C'mon, Wild Bill. Little walky walky.

dialogue.raw_text: Don't you call me that! Wild Bill Hickock wasn't no range rider! He was just a bushwackin' John Law! Dumb sonovabitch sat with his back to the door and kilt by a drunk!

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, my suds and body! A history lesson! You just never know what you're gonna get when you come to work everyday on the Green Mile. Thank you, Wild Bill.

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, not in there! C'mon now, I'll be good! Honest Injun I will! No! No! Ummmmhhhh...urg...ah!

dialogue.raw_text: Holy Christ, he's pitchin' a fit!

dialogue.raw_text: He'll be fine, boys. Trust me on this one.

direction.raw_text: ...and Billy staggers to his feet in the straitjacket, inarticulate with rage, starts throwing himself against the door, screaming at the top of his lungs.

direction.raw_text: Paul and Brutal unlock the restraint room. Billy looks up from the corner, pale and drained. Softly:

dialogue.raw_text: I learnt my lesson. I'll be good.

direction.raw_text: Billy's back in his cell, quiet for a change. Toot-Toot is outside the bars, mopping the floor. Billy notices a chocolate Moon Pie in Toot's shirt pocket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Toot looks around. Nobody's watching, and a nickel's a nickel. He steps to Billy's bars, swaps the Moon Pie for the money. Toot hurries away. Billy unwraps the Moon Pie, makes sure he's not being watched...and crams the entire thing into his mouth...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : ...and here comes Brutal strolling down the Mile, doing a cell check and jotting on a clipboard. He pauses, seeing: Billy at his bars. Just standing there staring. His cheeks bulging way out. Brutal steps closer, fascinated...what the fuck is that. Billy waits until he's just a bit closer-- --and he slams his fists against his own cheeks, propelling a disgusting spew of liquefied chocolate sludge into Brutal's face. Billy falls back onto his bunk, shrieking with laughter:

direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Pssss. Hey. Give'ya nickel for that Moon Pie.

dialogue.raw_text: Li'l Black Sambo, yassuh, boss, yassuh, howdoo you do?

dialogue.raw_text: (beat, calmly) Hope your bags are packed.

dialogue.raw_text: The Moon Pie thing was pretty original. Gotta give him that.

direction.raw_text: Paul and Brutal appear at Del's bars with Harry and Dean.

direction.raw_text: Del swells with pride upon hearing this. He scrounges up Mr. Jingles props, steps from his cell, looks to Harry and Dean.

direction.raw_text: Del nods, beaming happily, looks to Coffey in his cell.

direction.raw_text: Brutal leads Del up the Mile, Paul and the others at their heels. Percy's at the duty desk. He smirks and rolls his eyes as Del goes by. The moment Brutal and Del are out the door... ...Toot emerges from Paul's office where he's been hiding.

dialogue.raw_text: Del, grab your things. Big day for you and Mr. Jingles.

dialogue.raw_text: Whatchoo talkin' bout?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Important folks heard about your mouse, wanna see him perform. Not just guards, either. One of them's a politician all the way from the state capital, I believe.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You fellas comin'?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We got other fish to fry just now, Del, but you knock 'em for a loop.

dialogue.raw_text: You knock 'em for a loop like Mr. Harry says, Del.

dialogue.raw_text: Let's move along briskly, folks. There's not much time.

direction.raw_text: Headlights come over the rise. The truck appears, rumbling down toward the house. The world is isolated and still.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Harry stops and cuts the engine, leaving the headlights on. Silence now, save for the trilling of crickets.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul and Brutal both look terrified now that they're actually here. An urgent whisper:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lights are coming on inside the house. Coffey rises and steps down from the truck, pulling Paul along. Brutal follows them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul and Brutal walk to the front door as the lights inside the house keep clicking on. The last one finally comes on over the stoop, the front door opens a crack...and the twin barrels of a shotgun poke out into the night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The door swings wider, revealing Hal's face gaunt and haggard in the yellow porch light, stunned to see them:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hal doesn't, aiming past them at the truck in the yard.

direction.raw_text: A frozen moment. Hal mortified. Paul gives him a look--is that Melinda? Hal's shotgun shifts back to Coffey--but Paul steps in front of the muzzle.

direction.raw_text: Coffey enters, trailed by the others. Paul pauses, horrified. The woman propped in bed barely resembles Melinda Moores anymore--she looks made up like a Halloween witch, her livid skin hanging in a loose trail of wrinkles, one corner of her mouth twisted. Yellowish bile stains her chin and the front of her nightgown. Her hair has gone white and straw-like, her eyes glowering at Coffey with lively, irrational interest:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hal groans with despair. Coffey just stands there for a moment, watching her from a distance, then approaches the bed...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...but as he draws closer, a change occurs. Her features soften, her eyes become more sane and aware.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Coffey sits on the edge of the bed. The lights seem to flare hotter and brighter. Tears are forming in Melinda's eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She lays back, staring at him with shining fascination. The world seems to be slowing down, growing very still indeed... ...and he starts bending slowly toward her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He comes closer...closer still...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He brushes her forehead with his lips...the gentlest whisper of a kiss...then moves his mouth down to hers. For a moment we can see one of her eyes staring past him, filling with an expression of surprise... ...and then her face is lost to view as Coffey puts his lips on hers. We hear a soft whistling sound as he begins inhaling the air deeply from her lungs. Something hot and glowing starts passing between them, drawn on his breath... The men watch. The house seems to shudder in that moment, as if the entire world has shifted an inch to the right...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...and the grandfather clock stops ticking, the pendulum stopping dead, the glass face cracking neatly up the center...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...and a windowpane cracks. Then another. A picture falls off the wall. A lightbulb bursts, showering glass. Paul smells smoke, realizes the fringed coverlet of the bed has caught fire. Moving like a man in a dream, he reaches for the waterglass on the nightstand, douses the flames. Coffey keeps kissing Melinda in that deep and mysterious way, inhaling and inhaling, her hand held in his like a tiny white bird. For a moment we actually hear something screaming, as if some willful imp were being extracted by force... ...and then it's over. Coffey raises his head, revealing: Melinda's beautiful face. Her mouth no longer droops. Color is coming back to her hair. Her skin is shining with life. Coffey regards her raptly for a moment or two, then starts coughing violently. He turns away and drops to his knees, hacking like a man in the last stages of tuberculosis. Paul and his men are expecting Coffey to spit out the "bugs", but he doesn't--he just keeps coughing, deep and hard, barely finding time to snatch in the next breath of air. Hal goes to his wife, beyond stunned, sits at her side. She looks back at him with amazement, her face like a dirty mirror that's been suddenly wiped clean. John's coughing grows even worse. Brutal drops to his side and slaps his broad, spasming back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Coffey just keeps retching, eyes watering from the strain, spit flying from his mouth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul starts toward them. Coffey crawls away, pressing himself into a corner with his face against the wallpaper. He's still making gruesome deep hacking sounds, but getting it under control. He weakly waves Paul off--let me be. Paul looks to the bed. Hal sits with Melinda, stroking her brow. Color is blooming in her cheeks even as we watch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They both look at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hal bursts into tears. Melinda sits up, comforting him. Her eyes are drawn to the corner.

direction.raw_text: Coffey turns. His face is ashen gray, seriously ill.

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...but she pushes his hand gently aside. Hal watches in wonder as she stands, takes a first tentative step...and walks to Coffey. She gazes up and touches his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She undoes her necklace, holds it up for him. He hesitates, glances to Paul. Paul nods--it's all right. Coffey lowers his head. Melinda affixes the delicate chain around his neck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Her arms go around his neck, hugging him tightly as if she might never let go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Percy pauses near Coffey's cell, careless as always, getting his holster buckled--and a massive black arm grabs him through the bars. His SCREAM brings Paul and the others from the restraint room. Coffey's face is pressed so tight between his bars it looks like he's trying to push his head through. He draws his lips back, baring his teeth in an awful sneer... Percy whacks him with his baton. Coffey barely seems to feel it. He curls his free hand around the back of Percy's head, pulling him ever closer... ...and Percy's screams are muffled as their mouths come together. Coffey begins exhaling as if he'd held his breath for hours. Percy jerks like a fish on a hook, but can't get away. The men jump in, try to pry Percy loose, hollering for Coffey to let him go. The black "insects" are flowing from Coffey to Percy, swirling into his mouth, up his nose, down his throat. Several lightbulbs explode in their steel cages up and down the Mile. Percy's baton drops from his nerveless fingers and clatters to the floor, never to be picked up again. And then Coffey steps back, rubbing his mouth as if he's tasted something bad. The color has returned to his skin. Percy, however, is ashen gray. His expression is blank as a sheet of paper, not a trace of awareness in his eyes. The men are stunned. Paul raises his hand to Percy's face, snaps his fingers. Nothing. He tries again, clapping loudly. Percy reacts slightly, eyes fluttering, swaying a bit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Percy says nothing. He turns and walks slowly up the Mile, his movements vacant and disjointed. He comes to a swaying stop at Wild Bill's cell...and turns slowly to look in. Wild Bill is coming painfully around, groggily clutching his head. He looks up, see Percy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing for the longest moment. Percy just staring... ...and then he pulls his gun and empties it into Wild Bill as fast as he can pull the trigger. BAM!BAM!BAM!BAM!BAM!BAM! Bill takes all six rounds in the chest, reeling back across the cell. He hits the wall and slides down, leaving a smear, his face registering a final look of stunned surprise. Paul and the other tackle Percy and bring him down, wrestling the gun out of his hand. Dean is almost weeping:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Percy is flat on his back, staring up at nothing. The black "bugs" come drifting out of nose and mouth, swirling in the air over his head. They turn white and disappear. The men are speechless. Paul turns, sees Coffey sitting on the floor at his bars, watching.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Coffey reaches toward him, straining through the bars.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul hesitates, torn between reason and Coffey's pleading eyes. A whisper:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul can't help it. He has to. Their hands come together. Paul lurches wildly as that circuit starts blazing between them...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...and Paul sees: The Detterick twins. Kathe and Cora. Laughing and playing hopscotch in the dust under a later afternoon sun... A dinner table. Family having supper late in the day, basket of biscuits being passed. Twelve year old Howie Detterick taking it, passing it on... An hand with a paint brush slopping bright red paint on the side of a barn... Kathe skipping to the head of the hopscotch squares, turning and starting back, laughing in the sun... The paint brush slopping more paint, dripping like blood... Paul jerks and twists, trying to pull away, trying to break the circuit, but he can't, not till all is seen and done: Marjorie Detterick calling from the porch for everybody to come eat, supper's ready... A hammer pausing. Klaus looking down from atop the barn... The Detterick twins finishing their hopscotch, gathering their jump ropes from the dust, running across the yard... The basket of biscuits being passed to little Cora, who takes a biscuit and passes it on... Klaus coming down the ladder, calling to his daughters. The little girls running past the man with the paint brush, who turns and smile as they go by...it's Wild Bill. The basket of biscuits is passed one last time. A hand pulls one out, raises it for a bite. It's Wild Bill, smiling at the little girls as conversation flows around the table... Paul screams, trying to pull away, but: The porch door is kicked off its hinges just before dawn, a figure looming in the doorway. Kathe wakes, her scream cut short as the man's fist punches her hard in the face... Paul trembles violently as if riding the lightning himself, pleading for it to stop, but there's one last thing: Wild Bill looms over the terrified little girls like a horrendous boogeyman, whispers to Kathe:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And he drags them out into the coming dawn... ...as Coffey lets Paul go. Paul is gasping, back in the real world where his men are staring at him with wide eyes.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Based on what, honey? Some kind of magical vision I had?

dialogue.raw_text: Show this farmer--what's his name, Detterick?--show him a picture of Wild Bill. (off their looks) Why not? If Wharton was there...if the farmer can identify his picture and they know he was there...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Him being there in May doesn't mean he came back and killed those girls in June. Even if he was committing other crimes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They got their killer as far as they're concerned. Hell, Coffey's own lawyer would come throw the switch if we let him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then lie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lie? About what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tell them Wharton confessed to the crime. Brutus, you can back him up, say you heard it too. You can say that's what set Percy off. He shot Wharton because he couldn't stand thinking of what happened to those two little girls, it snapped his mind... (seeing their looks) ...what? What now?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We never reported anything like that. We would've, too, everybody knows it. It's part of our job.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Besides, confessing don't make it so. Slugs like Wild Bill lie about everything. Crimes they committed, women they had, even the weather.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But he was there! He painted their barn! He ate dinner with them!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All the more reason he might take credit for the crime. He's gonna fry anyway, so why not boast?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right. Then you've got to get John Coffey out on your own.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ma'am?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You did it once, didn't you? Only this time, don't bring him back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ma'am, your son's grown up and moved away. My kids are just starting kindergarten. Will you be the one to explain to them why their daddy's in prison?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Work out a plan. Make it look like a real escape.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Better be a plan an imbecile could dream up. Nobody'd believe it otherwise.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Even if we did think of something, it wouldn't do any good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why not? Just why the hell not?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Because he's a six-foot-eight-inch baldheaded black man with barely enough brains to feed himself. How long you think it'd be before he was recaptured? Two hours? Six?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you mean to kill him, you cowards? Do you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't touch me! Next week this time you'll be a murderer, no better than that man Wharton, so don't touch me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Paul is at the kitchen table in the wee hours, at his regular place, sipping his beer. Irving Berlin's "Remember" PLAYS SOFTLY on the radio. Jan comes down, looking miserable and exhausted. JAN I'm so sorry I called you a coward. I feel worse about that than anything I've ever said to you in our whole marriage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She can't help smiling at that. He returns the smile, offers her a sip of beer. She takes it, sits.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Even that time we went camping and you called me Old Stinky Sam?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Does Hal know? That Coffey's innocent, I mean? (Paul shakes his head) Can he help? Does he have the influence to do something about this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then don't tell him. If he can't help, don't tell him. Ever.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I won't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (beat) There's no way out of this for you, is there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. I've been thinking about it, too, believe me. (beat) Tell you the truth, honey. I've done some things in my life I'm not proud of, but this is the first time I've ever felt in real danger of hell.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hell? Oh Paul... (touches his face) Talk to him. Talk to John. Find out what he wants.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Coffey sits quietly in his cell, a solitary firefly flitting in circles around his finger. Paul and the men appear. The firefly flits away, vanishing through Coffey's tiny window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brutal unlocks his cell. Paul enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Coffey gives it some careful thought.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Coffey gives him a look--please.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul sits, working himself up to it:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul hesitates, emotions swirling, trying to find the right words.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Coffey hesitates--now he's the one trying to find the right words, trying to make Paul understand:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: By now, Paul is blinking back tears. Softly:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Coffey thinks about this long and hard, finally looks up.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hello, boss.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hello, John.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I guess you know we're coming down to it now. Another couple of days. (beat) Is there anything special you'd like for dinner that night? We can rustle you up most anything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Meatloaf be nice. Mashed taters with gravy. Okra, maybe. I's not picky.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What about a preacher? Someone you could say a little prayer with?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't want no preacher. You can say a prayer, if you want. I could get kneebound with you, I guess.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: S'pose I could, if it came to that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: John, I have to ask you something very important right now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know what you gonna say. You don' have to say it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I do. I do have to. (beat) John, tell me what you want me to do. You want me to take you out of here? Just let you run away? See how far you can get?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why would you do such a foolish thing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: On the day of my judgement, when I stand before God, and He asks me why did I kill one of his true miracles, what am I gonna say? That is was my job? My job?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You tell God the Father it was a kindness you done. (takes his hand) I know you hurtin' and worryin', I can feel it on you, but you oughtta quit on it now. Because I want it over and done. I do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm tired, boss. Tired of bein' on the road, lonely as a sparrow in the rain. Tired of not ever having me a buddy to be with, or tell me where we's coming from or going to, or why. Mostly I'm tired of people being ugly to each other. I'm tired of all the pain I feel and hear in the world ever' day. There's too much of it. It's like pieces of glass in my head all the time. Can you understand?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, John. I think I can.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There must be something we can do for you, John. There must be something you want.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I ain't never seen me a flicker show.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: gazing with wide-eyed, open-mouthed wonder, the light of a motion picture projector flickering on his skin...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...while Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers dance up there on the big screen, images flowing in magical black and silver tone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul and the men are scattered about in the otherwise empty auditorium, also watching.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (singing) Heaven, I'm in heaven...and my heart beats so that I can hardly speak...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Toot operates the projector, peering through the tiny window into the theater. He yawns, glances at his watch. Late.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fred and Ginger are now in the most passionate and graceful part of the dance. Irving Berlin's music swells.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: can't believe what he's seeing. He's so excited his breath is caught in his throat. Softly:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Why, they's angels. Angels. Just like up in heaven...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: come marching up the Green Mile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul appears at the bars with Brutal, Harry, and Dean. Nothing is said. Coffey knows why they're here. He rises as Brutal unlocks the cell, slides the door open. Coffey steps out, looks around at their dazed and sad faces.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul indicates St. Christopher medal around John's neck:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: John lets him take the necklace. Paul pockets it. They start to walk the Mile as:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He laughs at the memory of it, then grows more serious:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Behind them, Dean stifles a sob.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I be all right, fellas. This here's the hard part. I be all right in a little while.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: John, I should have that just for now. I'll give it back after.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know, I fell asleep this afternoon and had me a dream. I dreamed about Del's mouse.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you, John?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I dreamed he got down to that place Boss Howell talked about, that Mouseville place. I dreamed there was kids, and how they laughed at his tricks! My!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I dreamed those two little blonde- headed girls were there. They 'us laughing, too. I put my arms around 'em and sat 'em on my knees, and there 'us no blood comin' outta their hair and they 'us fine. We all watch Mr. Jingles roll that spool, and how we did laugh. Fit to bus', we was.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Coffey kneels. Paul joins him, self-conscious and uncertain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul nods--strength it is. Dean surprises Brutal and Harry by also kneeling. Brutal and Harry hesitate...then join them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul starts to rise, but Coffey takes his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Coffey closes his eyes, frowning in deep concentration.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And Paul sees: Kathe and Cora Detterick kneeling together in the enclosed porch that night, just before their bedtime:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And then the vision is gone as:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Coffey rises, offers Paul his hand, helps him up.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What should we pray for, John?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Strength?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: God, please help us finish what we've started, and please welcome this man, John Coffey--like the drink, but not spelled the same-- into heaven and give him peace. Please help us to see him off the best we can and let nothing go wrong. Amen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know a prayer I once heard. Can I say it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You go right ahead, John. Take all the time you need.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Baby Jesus, meek and mild, pray for me...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...and every child. Be my strength, be my friend...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...be with me until the end. Amen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Full house tonight. Bill Dodge is waiting at Old Sparky. Silence as Coffey is led in, all eyes on him. Klaus and Marjorie Detterick are in the front row. She mutters:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Die slow, you bastard.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: is faltering as Paul and Brutal bring him to the chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Coffey tries to take comfort in it, but flinches as:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She dissolves into tears. Klaus pulls her against his shoulder, looking dazed by the whole thing. Paul and Brutal turn John around, sit him down. Paul notices Dean crying again, his back to the witnesses. They kneel to apply the leg clamps, while Brutal and Harry secure the arms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dean nods, wiping his face with the sleeve of his coat. They rise, stepping back. This time, Paul's out front:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Van Hay cranks the generator. The lights flare hotter and brighter. It's just like in Melinda's bedroom the night Coffey cured her with a kiss. Airless and bright, dreamlike.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: John hesitates, nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brutal takes the mask from the hook to draw it over Coffey's head. Coffey looks to Paul with terrified, pleading eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brutal puts the mask back, proceeds with the sponge.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: They's a lot of folks here hate me. A lot. I can feel it. Like bees stinging me. It hurts.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Feel how we feel, then. We don't hate you--can you feel that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Kill him twice, you boys! You go on and kill that raping baby- killer twice, that'd be fine!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wipe you face before you stand up, Dean.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Roll on one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Does it hurt yet? I hope it does! I hope it hurts like hell!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: John Coffey...you have been condemned to die in the electric chair by a jury of your peers...sentence imposed by a judge in good standing in this state. Do you have anything to say before sentence is carried out?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry for what I am.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You ought to be! Oh, you monster, you damn well ought to be!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please, boss, don't put that thing over my face. Don't put me in the dark, I's afraid of the dark.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right, John.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: S The cap is lowered, the straps drawn. Coffey is breathing fast, terrified, muttering under his breath:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...heaven...I'm in heaven... heaven...heaven...heaven...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: sit and wait, barely breathing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is poised at the switch, wondering why the order won't come.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is staring at Coffey, unable to say the words.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul can't. He reaches out and touches Coffey's hand. Their fingers clasp. In that moment, staring into his eyes, Paul hears the last thought that ever goes through Coffey's head:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Their fingers disengage. Paul steps back, eyes still locked with Coffey's, and says the hardest words he's ever spoken:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Van Hay throws the switch. Coffey surges forward, fingers splayed and jittering past Old Sparky's arms. Lights begin blowing out all over the Mile, raining shattered glass and sparks. Some of the witnesses scream. A thin line of blood comes trickling out of Klaus Detterick's nose. He reaches up, absently wipes it away. Coffey's eyes are locked on Paul's, riding the lightning all the way. He finally slumps. Van Hay kills the current. Coffey's expression is peaceful, as if sleeping. A final pair of tears drift gently down his cheeks.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (whispers) Paul. You have to say it. You have to give the order.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (whispered V.O.) He kill 'em with they love. That's how it is ever' day. All over the worl'...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Roll on two.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Paul ever so carefully replaces the St. Christopher's medal around Coffey's neck. They wheel him down the tunnel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul drives home, his heart numb.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul pulls in, cuts the engine. He sits for a moment, then gets out and heads for the house. The door opens. Jan steps out in her nightgown and robe to meet him on the stairs. She takes him in her arms. Paul can't hold it back anymore. He breaks down sobbing against her as we
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's late in the day as:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: That was the last execution I ever took part in. Just couldn't do it anymore after that. Brutal either. We both transferred out, took jobs with Boys' Correctional. (beat, nods) That was all right. Catch 'em young, that became my motto. Might even have done some good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: SHIFTS TO Elaine listening. Uncertain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She shakes her head. Paul thinks for a moment, comes to a decision.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You don't believe me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't imagine you would lie to me, Paul. It's just that...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...It's quite a story.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. Quite a story. (pause) One thing I don't understand. You said you and Jan had a grownup son in 1935. Is that right? (Paul nods) But if that's true...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The math doesn't work, does it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You feel up to a walk?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The rain has mostly stopped. Brad Dolan, back in street clothes, gets in his pickup truck and drives away...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NURSING HOME - DAY ...while Paul and Elaine watch from a window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This time, we see two red specks trudging slowly up the ridge toward the treeline.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul brings Elaine along the wooded path into view of the storage shacks. They're both wearing ponchos.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He gives her a smile, offers his hand. She takes it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: There. It's in there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Paul? This thing you want to show me. Is it scary?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Scary? No. Not really.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We see Paul approach through the grimy window as before, this time bringing Elaine. ANGLE SHIFTS to the door as they arrive, creaking open on rusty hinges to reveal them. They enter. Elaine looks around at the musty nooks and crannies, wondering what they're doing here. Paul touchers arm, directs her attention:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Elaine moves closer, sees it on the dusty floorboards: An old cigar box. For a moment, she doesn't know what to make of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Elaine's breath catches in her throat... ...as a pair of bright oilspot eyes peer over the edge of the cigar box. It's a mouse. His fur, once brown, is now all gray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul gets down on the floor, holds out his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The mouse tries several times to get over the side of the cigar box before he finally makes it. He comes to them, hobbling and crippled with arthritis. Paul pulls a slice of toast from his pocket, breaks off a small piece for the mouse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul says nothing, just pulls a spool from his pocket. Mr. Jingles might be old, but he's as obsessed as ever. He gets ready to fetch, eyes riveted to the spool. Softly:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul tosses the spool. The mouse limps painfully after it. He reaches it, goes around...and has to lay down to catch his breath. Elaine starts forward, but Paul holds her back. After a moment, Mr. Jingles finds his feet again. He rises and starts nosing the spool back to Paul.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He glances around at the shack with a sad smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They gasp and spin. Brad Dolan stands in the doorway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pauses, seeing Mr. Jingles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brad grabs an old garden hoe--the blade's rusted, but still sharp enough to cut a mouse in two.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul rushes in front of Brad, fists clenched, yelling:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brad gives Paul a hard shove, pins him against the wall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Elaine is suddenly at Brad's elbow, seething with fury:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brad's smile falters. Elaine steps closer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brad eases his grip on Paul...and backs off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brad flushes red, heads for the door. He pauses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And off he goes. Paul tries to control the shaking in his hands, looks to Elaine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul bends down, picks Mr. Jingles up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The mouse stretches his neck forward, nose twitching, smelling Paul's breath. Paul looks to Elaine. Softly:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul looks at the mouse, strokes him gently between the ears.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: There.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey. Wake up, old boy. Wake up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Paul? It isn't...it can't be...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come over here, boy. Come on over her and see this lady.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That can't be Mr. Jingles.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Messieurs et mesdames. Beinvenue au cirque du mousie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, Paul. Don't make him do it again. I can't bear to watch.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (softly) But he loves it so much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This isn't exactly the Mouseville we had in mind...but we make do, don't we, old fella?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) As I live and breathe!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fooled you, didn't I Got yourself a little love nest here, I see...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...what the fuck? Is that a mouse?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't hurt him, okay? Okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's a goddamn mouse, y'old fool, they carry all kind'a disease...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...now step aside.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You leave him alone, Percy! You leave him alone, or by God I'll--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who you calling Percy? Name's Brad, you senile fucker. And I'm gonna nail that mouse, you can take that to the everfucking bank.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How dare you? Get out!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Piss off, you wrinkeldy old bitch. Me and Paulie are talking.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: His name is Mr. Edgecomb. If you ever call him Paulie again, your days of employment at Georgia Pines will end.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who the hell you think you are?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am the grandmother of the man who is currently Speaker of the Georgia House of Representatives. A man who loves his relatives, Mr. Dolan. All it would take is a phone call.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: At first I thought I'd let you be. I'm old, and that seemed easiest. But when my friends are threatened and abused, I do not let it be. (icy beat) Now get out, or you won't work another day here. Not another hour. I swear it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't know what you're getting so het up about. Just a damn mouse.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Get out, you ignorant man. What little mind you have is ugly and misdirected.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't bother coming back here tomorrow...Mr. Edgecomb Gonna be a new lock on this door. This is off-limits to residents, no matter what Mrs. My Shit Don't Stink has to say about it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Little trick I learned from Percy Wetmore.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is your grandson really Speaker of the House?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You gonna thank the lady? She just saved your old mousie hide.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think Mr. Jingles happened by accident. I think when we electrocuted Del, and it all went so badly...well, John could feel it, you know...and I think a tiny part of whatever was inside of him just leapt out... (beat) Me, I was no accident. John had to give me a little part of himself...a gift, like...so I could see for myself what Wild Bill had done. When John did that, a part of whatever power worked through him spilled into me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He...what? Infected you with life?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's as good a word as any. He infected us both, didn't he, Mr. Jingles. With life. (beat) I'm a hundred and five years old, Elaine. I was forty the year John Coffey walked the Green Mile.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...oh my God...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: on Paul as:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I haven't even had a cold since
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . I've had to watch my friends and loved ones die off through the years...Hal and Melinda...Brutus Howell...my wife...my son... (beat) ...and you, Elaine. You'd die, too, and my curse is knowing I'll be there to see it...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . FUNERAL HOME - DAY Paul, dressed in a dark suit, comes up the aisle. ANGLE SHIFTS to reveal Elaine Connelly lying in the open casket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul lays a rose atop the casket.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) ...that's my punishment, you see? My punishment for letting John Coffey ride the lightning...for killing a miracle of God...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) ...you'll be gone, like all the others, and I'll have to stay...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Paul stands at the graveside as the casket is lowered.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns and walks away.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) I'll die eventually, I imagine. I have no illusions of immortality. But I will have wished for death long before death finds me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) In truth, I wish for it already.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Empty and silent. Young Paul walks the Mile alone, listening to the quiet. He pauses, seeing something. A whisper:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is Mr. Jingles. The little mouse is peering from under the restraint room door. He's come home, looking bedraggled. Paul bends down, gently picks him up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul turns and head back up the Green Mile, carrying the mouse cupped in his hands as we
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Jingles?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where you been, boy? I've been worried about you. You hungry?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . NURSING HOME - DAY Young Paul transforms into Old Paul in the dissolve, the corridor of the Green Mile becoming the corridor of the nursing home. He's walking along, holding the little mouse the same way he did over sixty years ago.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) I lie in bed most nights, thinking about it. And I wait...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Paul lies awake, staring at the moon outside his window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks over at the nightstand...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...and WE PAN to reveal Mr. Jingles sleeping fitfully in his cigar box, chasing that spool in his dreams as we
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) I think about all the people I've loved, now long gone. I think about my beautiful Jan, and how I lost her so many years ago. I think about all of us walking our own Green Mile, each in our own time. But one thought, more than any other, keeps me awake most nights... (beat) ...if he could make a mouse live so long, how much longer do I have?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) We each owe a death, there are no exceptions, but sometimes, oh God, the Green Mile is so long...
dialogue.name: dialogue
